Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) in Marine and Estuarine Science
Award.AbstractNarration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites award has been made to the University of Maryland Eastern Shore that will provide research training for 8 students each year, for 10 weeks during the summers of 2012- 2014. The program is supported by the Directorate for Biological Science, Division of Biological Infrastructure, the Directorate for Geosciences, Division of Ocean Sciences, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Human Resources HBCU-UP program. The program focuses on marine and estuarine science. Students are offered a broad range of mentorship in various areas including, but not limited, to fish and macroinvertebrate population dynamics, marine microbiology and parasitology, molecular biology, genetics, marine botany, environmental chemistry, and ecotoxicology. Students, particularly rising sophomores, are recruited by various means, including use of flyers describing the program and by digital-based advertising. Selection of students is based on academic record, letters of recommendation, and potential for further studies in the areas of marine and environmental science. Students receive a stipend and travel support; housing and board are covered. In addition to research, weekly workshops are conducted to train students in writing a research proposal, analyzing data, scientific ethics, and various contemporary topics such as global climate change. Apart from weekly workshops, REU interns also participate in field trips along the pristine Pocomoke River, and at an internationally recognized wetland on the lower eastern shore of Maryland. At the end of the summer, REU interns present research they have conducted with their faculty mentors during a symposium that is held at the Paul S. Sarbanes Coastal Ecology Center. Interns prepare a short report of their research which is compiled in form of symposium proceedings. Students are tracked to determine if they have continued to maintain interest in marine and environmental science, their career paths, and the lasting influences of the research experience. The program will be assessed using various means, including use of an REU common assessment tool. Students with limited opportunities for research, particularly in coastal systems, and from groups under-represented in science are particularly encouraged to apply. Additional information on the REU internship can be found at www.umes.edu/reu, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Paulinus Chigbu at: pchigbu@umes.edu), or Co-PI (Dr. Eric May at: ebmay@umes.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the University of Maryland Eastern Shore (UMES) REU program was to recruit, mentor and prepare undergraduates, particularly underrepresented minorities, in laboratory and/or field research focusing on the ecology of coastal rivers, lagoons and estuaries in Maryland. Students had opportunities to work in various research areas including, but not limited to, the population dynamics of fish and macroinvertebrates, marine microbiology and parasitology, molecular biology and genetics, marine botany, environmental chemistry, and ecotoxicology.

From 2012 to 2014, a total of thirty-seven (37) students, selected from more than 25 institutions across the United States took part in the 10 week REU program.  The interns, the majority of whom were rising sophomores and rising juniors, participated in hands-on research experience, professional
development activities such as lectures, workshops, and seminars, and in field trips that were educationally enriching. Interns worked on various research projects some of which examined the ecology of species in coastal and estuarine waters, particularly in the Maryland Coastal Bays (MCBs). Data generated as a result of some of these studies have helped to enhance our knowledge of these systems, and have formed or will form parts of manuscripts that will be submitted for publication in peer-reviewed journals.   

The project has made a significant impact on the development of human resources in marine and estuarine science, particularly those belonging to members of underrepresented groups.  Of the 37 interns in the program
from 2012 to 2014, 92% belonged to underrepresented minority groups, and 65% were females.  Most of the students especially those supported with NSF REU funds had just completed high school, freshman or sophomore
years before participating in the REU program.  By participating in the REU program, undergraduates at lower levels have become better prepared for junior and senior level classes, for subsequent participation in REU programs targeting upper class levels, and for graduate school.  

Interns responses to survey questions indicated that they had significant gains from their participation in the research program. The project has helped to increase ocean literacy by exposing undergraduate students to various areas of marine and estuarine sciences. It has also helped to strengthen the academic backgrounds of the interns through research experiences and professional development activities which have been demonstrated to help increase undergraduate student retention, academic performance, and the likelihood of success in graduate school. Thus, the program has helped to impact positively on the STEM workforce development
in the United States.
